00018 #ifndef __TLM_DMI_H__
00019 #define __TLM_DMI_H__
00020 
00021 #include <systemc>
00022 
00023 // TLM_LITTLE_ENDIAN is defined there:
00024 #include "tlm_h/tlm_trans/tlm_generic_payload/tlm_helpers.h"
00025 
00026 namespace tlm {
00027 
00028 
00029 // Class for signaling the requested access type to the target. The target
00030 // is allowed to promote READ or WRITE requests to READ_WRITE.
00031 //
00032 // The tlm_direct_mem_if is templated over this interface, so that the user
00033 // has the opportunity to stick extensions into the class. One application
00034 // example could be to communicate a CPU ID to the target for situations
00035 // where address handling might be different for each CPU.
00036 class tlm_dmi_mode
00037 {
00038 public:
00039   enum Type { READ = 0x1, WRITE = 0x2, READ_WRITE = READ|WRITE };
00040   Type type;
00041     
00042 };
00043 
00044 class tlm_dmi
00045 {
00046 public:
00047 
00048   tlm_dmi()
00049   {
00050     init();
00051   }
00052   
00053   void init()
00054   {
00055     dmi_ptr           = 0;
00056     dmi_start_address = 0x0;
00057     dmi_end_address   = (sc_dt::uint64)-1;
00058     read_latency      = sc_core::SC_ZERO_TIME;
00059     write_latency     = sc_core::SC_ZERO_TIME;
00060     endianness        = TLM_LITTLE_ENDIAN;
00061   }
00062   
00063   // If the forward call is successful, the target returns the dmi_ptr,
00064   // which must point to the data element corresponding to the
00065   // dmi_start_address. The data is organized as a byte array with the
00066   // endianness of the target (endianness member of the tlm_dmi struct).
00067   unsigned char* dmi_ptr;
00068   
00069   // The absolute start and end addresses of the DMI region. If the decoder
00070   // logic in the interconnect changes the address field e.g. by masking, the
00071   // interconnect is responsible to transform the relative address back to an
00072   // absolute address again.
00073   sc_dt::uint64 dmi_start_address;
00074   sc_dt::uint64 dmi_end_address;
00075 
00076   // These members define the latency of read/write transactions. The
00077   // initiator must initialize these members to zero before requesting a
00078   // dmi pointer, because both the interconnect as well as the target can
00079   // add to the total transaction latency.
00080   // Depending on the 'type' attribute only one, or both of these attributes
00081   // will be valid.
00082   sc_core::sc_time  read_latency;
00083   sc_core::sc_time  write_latency;
00084   
00085   // The target sets the endianness of the data in the dmi_ptr array.
00086   tlm_endianness endianness;
00087 };
00088 
00089 } // namespace tlm
00090 
00091 #endif /* TLM_DMI_HEADER */
